title: The most expensive Man Utd sales of all time : Ronaldo holds top spot , Beckham still in top 10

While Manchester United are renowned for spending big on new signings, theyâ€™ve often struggled to recoup money when selling players.
United have been looking to offload a number of first-team players this summer as they try to fund Ruben Amorimâ€™s squad rebuild.
Weâ€™ve taken a look at the 10 most expensive sales in Manchester Unitedâ€™s history and how those players fared after leaving the club.
Note: weâ€™ve not included Henrikh Mkhitaryan, who joined Arsenal in an infamous swap deal that saw Alexis Sanchez move in the opposite direction without any money being exchanged.

Having played under Louis van Gaal at the 2014 World Cup, Depay completed a Â£25million move to United a year later and reunited with the manager.
But the Netherlands international fell out of favour following the arrival of Jose Mourinho at Old Trafford in the summer of 2016.
He made just one start under Mourinho and joined Lyon in January 2017 in a deal worth Â£16million and another Â£5.7million in add-ons.
The forward registered 76 goals and 55 assists in 178 appearances for the Ligue 1 side before joining Barcelona on a free transfer at the end of the 2020/21 season.

Alongside Depay, Schneiderlin also endured a disappointing 18-month stint at United after arriving at Old Trafford in the summer of 2015.
He moved to Everton in a deal worth up to Â£24million with add-ons and linked up with Ronald Koeman, whom he played for at Southampton.
But the midfielder also failed to find his best form at Goodison Park and was sold to Ligue 1 side Nice for just Â£2million in 2020.
8. David Beckham â€“ Â£24.5m
Year: 2003
To: Real Madrid
Man Utd appearances: 394
Man Utd goals: 85
Beckham left United due to a breakdown in his relationship with Sir Alex Ferguson, who famously kicked a boot at the winger after an FA Cup defeat against Arsenal.
â€œThe next day the story was in the press,â€ Ferguson said. â€œIn public, an Alice band highlighted the damage inflicted by the boot. It was in those days that I told the board David had to go.
â€œMy message would have been familiar to board members who knew me. The minute a Manchester United player thought he was bigger than the manager, he had to go.â€
Real Madrid fought off competition from Barcelona to sign Beckham, paying an initial Â£17.5million and another Â£7million in potential add-ons.
The former England international registered 20 goals and 51 assists in 159 appearances for Madrid and won a La Liga title in 2006/07.
7. Scott McTominay â€“ Â£25.7m
Year: 2024
To: Napoli
Man Utd appearances: 255
Man Utd goals: 29
McTominay decided to leave United in search of regular first-team football and completed a Â£25.7million move to Napoli in 2024, ending his 22-year association with the club.
The sale of the academy graduate represented â€˜pure profitâ€™ in the books, which helped United operate within the Premier Leagueâ€™s Profit and Sustainability Rules (PSR).
But the Scotland international won the Serie A title in his debut season and was also voted the leagueâ€™s most valuable player after contributing 12 goals and six assists.
â€œScotty was a player that you look for in a dressing room to get you where you want to be,â€ former United coach Benni McCarthy said.
â€œTo let him go for what was a small transfer fee was a big shame. I think everyone at the club regrets that decision.â€

6. Mason Greenwood â€“ Â£26.6m
Year: 2024
To: Marseille
Man Utd appearances: 129

Greenwoodâ€™s United career was brought to a sudden halt when he was arrested in January 2022 and later charged with attempted rape, controlling and coercive behaviour and assault.
While the charges against him were dropped, United ultimately opted against reintegrating the striker back into the team.
He had an impressive loan spell at Getafe in 2023/24 before completing a permanent move to Marseille, who paid United an initial Â£23.2million and a further Â£3.4million in potential add-ons.
The 23-year-old made an immediate impact and netted 21 goals in his debut season, making him the joint top scorer in Ligue 1 in 2024/25.
5. Dan James â€“ Â£30m
Year: 2021
To: Leeds
Man Utd appearances: 74
Man Utd goals: 9
The first signing of the Ole Gunnar Solskjaer era, James joined United from Swansea City in a Â£15million deal in 2019 and proved a useful squad player at Old Trafford.
But the Wales international was deemed surplus to requirements after United signed Jadon Sancho and Cristiano Ronaldo in the summer of 2021.
United still made a profit by selling him to Leeds in a deal worth an initial Â£25million and another Â£5million in potential add-ons.
The winger had a difficult debut season at Elland Road and was sent on loan to Fulham but has since turned things around, winning the Leeds Player of the Year award in 2024/25.
4. Alejandro Garnacho â€“ Â£40m
Year: 2025
To: Chelsea
Man Utd appearances: 144
Man Utd goals: 26
Having joined United in 2020 as a 16-year-old, Garnacho worked his way through the academy and established himself as a key player under Erik ten Hag.
But the winger fell out of favour under Ruben Amorim and criticised the manager after being named on the bench for the 2024/25 Europa League final defeat against Tottenham.
He was told to find a new club a few days later and joined Chelsea in a deal worth Â£40million after United agreed to lower their Â£60million asking price.
The deal, which also includes a 10 per cent sell-on clause, makes the Argentina international the most expensive academy graduate sale in Unitedâ€™s history.
3. Angel Di Maria â€“ Â£44.3m
Year: 2015
To: Paris Saint-Germain
Man Utd appearances: 32
Man Utd goals: 4
United agreed to pay a then-British transfer record fee of Â£59.7million to sign Di Maria from Real Madrid in the summer of 2014.
The Argentina international failed to justify that price tag and joined Paris Saint-Germain in a Â£44.3million deal after just one season at Old Trafford.
He got his career back on track and registered 93 goals and 119 assists during a seven-year stint in Paris and also won 19 trophies, including five Ligue 1 titles.

The most expensive signing in Unitedâ€™s history, Lukaku was bought for Â£90million in the summer of 2017 and scored 27 goals in his debut season at Old Trafford.
But the goals dried up in his second season, and he was sold to Inter Milan in a deal worth Â£64.7million and a further Â£9.2million in potential add-ons.
The Belgium international rediscovered his goalscoring form at Inter, scoring 64 goals in 95 appearances in all competitions. He also won the Serie A title in the 2020/21 season before returning to England with Chelsea.
1. Cristiano Ronaldo â€“ Â£80m
Year: 2009
To: Real Madrid
Man Utd appearances (first spell): 292
Man Utd goals (first spell): 118
After joining United from Sporting in 2003, Ronaldo developed into one of the best players in the world and picked up his first Ballon dâ€™Or award.
But he expressed his desire to move to Real Madrid, who spent a then world-record Â£80million fee to prise him away from Old Trafford in the summer of 2009.
â€œI respect everyoneâ€™s opinion but I donâ€™t agree with these people (who have criticised the fee),â€ Ronaldo said after joining Madrid.
â€œIf Real Madrid have paid so much money it is because they wanted me and considered it good value. I am going to do all I can to play well and prove the money they paid for me has been well spent.â€
The Portugal international didnâ€™t disappoint, scoring 438 goals in 450 appearances for Madrid while winning two La Liga titles, two Copa del Reys and four Champions Leagues.
